title: Cryoprecipitate Dosing for Fibrinogen Replacement
description: Calculates the required dose of cryoprecipitate units needed to achieve target fibrinogen levels in patients with fibrinogen deficiency or hypofibrinogenemia

parameters.name: patient_sex
parameters.description: Patient biological sex for plasma volume calculation

parameters.name: fibrinogen_per_unit
parameters.description: Fibrinogen content per cryoprecipitate unit (default 200 mg)

ranges.interpretation: Small cryoprecipitate dose required. Monitor response with repeat fibrinogen levels.
Standard therapeutic dose. Consider pooled units (typically 10 units per pool) for efficient administration.
High dose replacement required. Consider alternative therapies like fibrinogen concentrate. Monitor for volume overload.
Very high dose requirement. Consider fibrinogen concentrate instead of cryoprecipitate. Ensure adequate vascular access and monitor for complications.

references: American Association of Blood Banks (AABB). Technical Manual, 20th Edition. 2020.
British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH). Guidelines for the use of fresh-frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate and cryosupernatant. Br J Haematol. 2004;126(1):11-28.
Stanworth SJ, Brunskill SJ, Hyde CJ, McClelland DB, Murphy MF. Is fresh frozen plasma clinically effective? A systematic review of randomized controlled trials. Br J Haematol. 2004;126(1):139-152.
American Red Cross. Circular of Information for the Use of Human Blood and Blood Components. 2017.
formula: Required Units = (Target Fibrinogen - Current Fibrinogen) × Plasma Volume / Fibrinogen per Unit; where Plasma Volume (dL) = Weight (kg) × Factor × (1 - Hematocrit); Factor = 0.07 for males, 0.065 for females
notes: Standard adult dose is typically 10 pooled units containing approximately 2000 mg fibrinogen
One unit of cryoprecipitate typically contains 150-250 mg fibrinogen (200 mg average)
Alternative dosing: 1 unit per 5-10 kg body weight increases fibrinogen by approximately 60-100 mg/dL
Critical fibrinogen threshold is <50-100 mg/dL requiring urgent replacement
For major bleeding, maintain fibrinogen >150-200 mg/dL
Monitor response with repeat coagulation studies 1-2 hours post-transfusion
Consider fibrinogen concentrate for patients requiring large doses or with volume restrictions
Each cryoprecipitate unit is typically 15-20 mL in volume
